      window.viHeadScriptSize = 38.43;
      window.NYTD = {};

      window.vi.pageType = { type: '', edge: 'vi-story'};

  var marks = ['first-paint', 'first-contentful-paint', 'userBtnRender', 'appRenderTime'];

  var observer = new window.PerformanceObserver(function(list) {
    var entries = list.getEntries();
    for (var i = 0; i < entries.length; i += 1) {
      var entry = entries[i];
      if (marks.indexOf(entry.name) > -1) {
        var performance = {};
        performance[entry.name] = Math.round(entry.duration || entry.startTime);
        (window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || []).push({
          event: 'performance',
          pageview: {
            performance: performance,
          },
        });
      }
    }
  });
 
  observer.observe({ entryTypes: ['mark', 'measure', 'paint'] });
} catch(e) {};

  (function initWebUnifiedTracking(root) {
  var _root;

  root = root || (typeof window !== 'undefined' ? window : undefined);
  var UnifiedTracking = ((_root = root) === null || _root === void 0 ? void 0 : _root.UnifiedTracking) || {};
  UnifiedTracking.context = 'web';

  if (!root) {
    return UnifiedTracking;
  }

  root.UnifiedTracking = UnifiedTracking;

  UnifiedTracking.sendAnalytic = function sendAnalytic(eventName, dataBlob) {
    root.dataLayer = root.dataLayer || [];

    if (Array.isArray(root.dataLayer)) {
      // Don't use a spread operator here for babel reasons
      dataBlob.event = dataBlob.event || eventName;
      root.dataLayer.push(dataBlob);
    }

    return Promise.resolve({
      success: true
    });
  };

  return UnifiedTracking;
})(window);

  function placeGpt() {
    var purrCookie = testCookie('nyt-purr');
    if (purrCookie && purrCookie.substring(4, 5) === 's' ||
        purrCookie && purrCookie.substring(4, 5) === 'a'
    ) return;
    var gptScript = document.createElement('script');
    gptScript.async = 'async';
    gptScript.src = '//securepubads.g.doubleclick.net/tag/js/gpt.js';
    document.head.appendChild(gptScript);
  }
  placeGpt();

1.176 1.11l.42.199-.497.009c-.481 0-.498.008-.447.19.172.564.85 1.162 1.606 1.422l.532.182-.464.277a4.833 4.833 0 0 1-2.3.641c-.387.009-.704.044-.704.07 0 .086 1.047.572 1.657.762 1.828.564 4 .32 5.631-.641 1.159-.685 2.318-2.045 2.859-3.363.292-.702.583-1.984.583-2.6 0-.398.026-.45.507-.927.283-.277.55-.58.6-.667.087-.165.078-.165-.36-.018-.73.26-.832.226-.472-.164.266-.278.584-.78.584-.928 0-.026-.129.018-.275.096a4.79 4.79 0 0 1-.755.294l-.464.148-.42-.286C9.66.467 9.335.293 9.163.24 8.725.12 8.055.137 7.66.276c-1.074.39-1.752 1.395-1.674 2.496z" fill="#000"></path></svg></a></li><li class="css-1xbhk30 email-share-item"><a href="mailto:?subject=NYTimes.com%3A%20A%20New%20Covid-19%20Crisis%3A%20Domestic%20Abuse%20Rises%20Worldwide&amp;body=From%20The%20New%20York%20Times%3A%0A%0AA%20New%20Covid-19%20Crisis%3A%20Domestic%20Abuse%20Rises%20Worldwide%0A%0AMovement%20restrictions%20aimed%20to%20stop%20the%20spread%20of%20the%20coronavirus%20may%20be%20making%20violence%20in%20homes%20more%20frequent%2C%20more%20severe%20and%20more%20dangerous.%0A%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2020%2F04%2F06%2Fworld%2Fcoronavirus-domestic-violence.html%3Fsmid%3Dem-share" 4.76.906 8.419zm13 0L9.174 4.761 13.906 0v8.418zM7.407 6.539l-1.13-1.137L.907 9h13l-5.37-3.598-1.13 1.137zM1.297 0h12.22l-6.11 5.095L1.297 0z" fill="#000"></path></svg></a></li><li class="css-1xbhk30 more-share-item"><div class="css-6n7j50"><button aria-haspopup="true" aria-expanded="false" aria-label="More sharing options ..." class="css-16ogagc" data-testid="" type="button"><svg class="css-107sgp6" viewBox="0 0 16 13" width="16" height="13"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M15.406 5.359L8.978 0v3.215C3.82 3.215.406 8.107.406 12.66 1.653 9.133 4.29 7.517 8.978 7.517v3.2l6.428-5.358z" fill="#000"></path></svg></button></div></li><li class="css-1xbhk30"></li><li class="css-1hztko0"></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="sizeLarge layoutHorizontal css-1ox9jel" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-bsn42l"><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 3dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 288dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/xxint-dvvirus1/merlin_170846187_ccb08010-f3cd-40de-957c-cc1118456b58-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=600"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/xxint-dvvirus1/merlin_170846187_ccb08010-f3cd-40de-957c-cc1118456b58-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1200"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/xxint-dvvirus1/merlin_170846187_ccb08010-f3cd-40de-957c-cc1118456b58-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1800"/><img alt="Movement limits imposed by countries around the world have forced people to spend much more time at home, leading to a surge in domestic abuse cases." class="css-11cwn6f" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/xxint-dvvirus1/merlin_170846187_ccb08010-f3cd-40de-957c-cc1118456b58-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/xxint-dvvirus1/merlin_170846187_ccb08010-f3cd-40de-957c-cc1118456b58-articleLarge.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/xxint-dvvirus1/merlin_170846187_ccb08010-f3cd-40de-957c-cc1118456b58-jumbo.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/xxint-dvvirus1/merlin_170846187_ccb08010-f3cd-40de-957c-cc1118456b58-superJumbo.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 80vw, 100vw" decoding="async"/></picture></div><figcaption class="css-17ai7jg e18f7pbr0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Movement limits imposed by countries around the world have forced people to spend much more time at home, leading to a surge in domestic abuse cases.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span>Federico Rios for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-18e8msd"><div class="css-vp77d3 epjyd6m0"><div class="css-hus3qt ey68jwv0" aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/amanda-taub" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Amanda Taub" title="Amanda Taub" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2019/07/16/reader-center/author-amanda-taub/author-amanda-taub-thumbLarge.png" class="css-1rjmmt7 ey68jwv2"/></a></div><div class="css-1baulvz"><p class="css-4z5zii e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/amanda-taub" class="css-brehiz e1jsehar0"><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline">Amanda Taub</span></a></p></div></div><ul class="css-1u1psjv epjyd6m3"><li class="css-ccw2r3 epjyd6m1"><time dateTime="2020-04-14T07:38:24-04:00" class="css-ld3wwf e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">Published <!-- -->April 6, 2020</span><span class="css-233int e16638kd4">Updated <!-- -->April 14, 2020</span></time></li></ul></div><div class="css-mdjrty"><a class="css-1s5aqv3" href="https://cn.nytimes.com/world/20200408/coronavirus-domestic-violence/" data-version="zh-hans" title="Read in Simplified Chinese">阅读简体中文版</a><a class="css-1s5aqv3" href="https://cn.nytimes.com/world/20200408/coronavirus-domestic-violence/zh-hant/" data-version="zh-hant" title="Read in Traditional Chinese">閱讀繁體中文版</a></div></header><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Add another public health crisis to the toll of the new coronavirus: Mounting data suggests that domestic abuse is acting like an opportunistic infection, flourishing in the conditions created by the pandemic.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">There was every reason to believe that the restrictions imposed to keep the virus from spreading would have such an effect, said Marianne Hester, a Bristol University sociologist who studies abusive relationships. Domestic violence goes up whenever families spend more time together, such as the Christmas and summer vacations, she said.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Now, with families in lockdown worldwide, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/15/us/domestic-violence-coronavirus.html" title="">hotlines are lighting up with abuse reports</a>, leaving governments trying to address a crisis that experts say they should have seen coming.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">[Read: </em><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/14/world/europe/russia-coronavirus-alcoholism.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">As coronavirus grips Russia, an age-old bane returns: drinking</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">]</em></p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">The United Nations called on Sunday for urgent action to combat the worldwide surge in domestic violence. “I urge all governments to put women’s safety first as they respond to the pandemic,” Secretary General António Guterres wrote on Twitter.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">But governments largely failed to prepare for the way the new public health measures would create opportunities for abusers to terrorize their victims.<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>Now, many are scrambling to offer services to those at risk.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">But, as with the response to the virus itself, the delays mean that irreparable harm may already have occurred.</p><h2 class="css-1aoo5yy eoo0vm40" id="link-7c916732">Lockdown and ‘Intimate Terrorism’</h2><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">As cities and towns across China locked down, a 26-year-old woman named Lele found herself entangled in more and more arguments with her husband, with whom she now had to spend every hour in their home in Anhui Province, in eastern China.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">On March 1, while Lele was holding her 11-month-old daughter, her husband began to beat her with a high chair. She is not sure how many times he hit her. Eventually, she says, one of her legs lost feeling and she fell to the ground, still holding the baby in her arms.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">A photograph she took after the incident shows the high chair lying on the floor in pieces, two of its metal legs snapped off — evidence of the force with which her husband wielded it against her. Another image documents Lele’s injuries: Nearly every inch of her lower legs was covered in bruises, a huge hematoma blooming on her left calf.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Lele — her full name is not being used for her safety —<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>said that her husband had abused her throughout their six-year relationship, but that the Covid-19 outbreak made things far worse.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“During the epidemic, we were unable to go outside, and our conflicts just grew bigger and bigger and more and more frequent,” she said. “Everything was exposed.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 3dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 288dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/XXint-dvvirus3/merlin_168726405_214d5c94-29aa-459c-b0c4-4fb2e9f603a7-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=600"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/XXint-dvvirus3/merlin_168726405_214d5c94-29aa-459c-b0c4-4fb2e9f603a7-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1200"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/XXint-dvvirus3/merlin_168726405_214d5c94-29aa-459c-b0c4-4fb2e9f603a7-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1800"/><img alt="Mounting data suggest that domestic abuse is flourishing in the conditions created by the pandemic." class="css-1m50asq" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/XXint-dvvirus3/merlin_168726405_214d5c94-29aa-459c-b0c4-4fb2e9f603a7-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/XXint-dvvirus3/merlin_168726405_214d5c94-29aa-459c-b0c4-4fb2e9f603a7-articleLarge.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/XXint-dvvirus3/merlin_168726405_214d5c94-29aa-459c-b0c4-4fb2e9f603a7-jumbo.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/04/02/world/XXint-dvvirus3/merlin_168726405_214d5c94-29aa-459c-b0c4-4fb2e9f603a7-superJumbo.jpg?quality=90&amp;auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 80vw, 100vw" decoding="async"/></picture></div><figcaption class="css-18crmh6 ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Mounting data suggest that domestic abuse is flourishing in the conditions created by the pandemic.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Yuyang Liu for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">As quarantines take effect around the world, that kind of “intimate terrorism” — a term many experts prefer for domestic violence — is flourishing.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">In China, a Beijing-based NGO dedicated to combating violence against women, Equality, has seen a surge in calls to its help line since early February, when the government locked down cities in Hubei Province, then the outbreak’s epicenter.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">In Spain, the emergency number for domestic violence received 18 percent more calls in the first two weeks of lockdown than in the same period a month earlier.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“We’ve been getting some very distressing calls, showing us clearly just how intense psychological as well as physical mistreatment can get when people are kept 24 hours a day together within a reduced space,” said Ana Bella, who set up <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.fundacionanabella.org/en/ana-bella/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">a foundation </a>to help other women after surviving domestic violence herself.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">On Thursday, the French police reported a nationwide spike of about 30 percent in domestic violence. Christophe Castaner, the French interior minister, said he had asked officers to be on the lookout for abuse.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“The risk increases due to confinement,” he said in an<a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/VALP/status/1243288744276492290" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"> interview on French television</a>.</p><h2 class="css-1aoo5yy eoo0vm40" id="link-5d4fce50">No Escape</h2><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">In Spain, with the help of women’s associations, The New York Times contacted women stuck at home with an abusive husband or partner and conducted interviews over WhatsApp.</p><div role="complementary" aria-labelledby="storyline-latest-updates" class="css-y1f5ai"><div class="css-8atqhb"><div class="css-nl7gl3"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/news-event/coronavirus">The Coronavirus Outbreak<!-- --> ›</a></div><h2 id="storyline-latest-updates" class="css-5o8lnh"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/01/23/world/covid-19-coronavirus">Latest Updates</a></h2><div class="css-rchdvv"><time class="css-101kej7" dateTime="2021-01-24T15:42:58.000Z"><span>Updated </span><div class="css-ki347z"><span class="css-1stvlmo">Jan. 24, 2021, 10:42 a.m. ET</span><span class="css-kpxlkr"></span></div></time><span class="css-1dv1kvn" aria-live="polite"></span></div><ul class="css-15zvb7e"><li class="css-6exgss"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/01/23/world/covid-19-coronavirus#as-americans-jostle-for-vaccinations-a-rhode-island-state-lawmaker-wants-to-punish-those-who-cut-the-line">As Americans jostle for vaccinations, a Rhode Island state lawmaker wants to punish those who cut the line.</a></li><li class="css-6exgss"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/01/23/world/covid-19-coronavirus#the-missouri-capitol-may-put-a-testing-clinic-in-the-basement-as-more-lawmakers-fall-ill">The Missouri Capitol may put a testing clinic in the basement as more lawmakers fall ill.</a></li><li class="css-6exgss"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/01/23/world/covid-19-coronavirus#vaccines-can-be-stretched-but-its-not-easy">Vaccines can be stretched, but it’s not easy.</a></li></ul><div class="css-gczbks styln-survey-component" id="storyline-survey-latest-updates"></div></div></div><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">One of them, Ana — who asked that her full name be withheld — shares an apartment with her partner, and says he has been regularly abusing her. He insists on total surveillance at all times. If she tries to lock herself in a room, he kicks the door until she opens it.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“I can’t even have privacy in the bathroom — and now I have to endure this in a lockdown,” she wrote in a message sent late at night, to hide the communication from her husband.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Judith Lewis Herman, a renowned trauma expert<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>at Harvard University Medical School, has found that the coercive methods domestic abusers use to control their partners and children “bear an uncanny resemblance” to those kidnappers use to control hostages and repressive regimes use to break the will of political prisoners.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-18crmh6 ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">“We can come to your place after the crisis,” the authorities are said to have told one abuse victim in China.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Yuyang Liu for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“The methods which enable one human being to control another are remarkably consistent,” she wrote in a widely cited 1992 <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.myptsd.com/gallery/-pdf/1-90.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">journal article</a>. “While perpetrators of organized political or sexual exploitation may instruct each other in coercive methods, perpetrators of domestic abuse appear to reinvent them.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">In addition to physical violence, which is not present in every abusive relationship, common tools of abuse include isolation from friends, family and employment; constant surveillance; strict, detailed rules for behavior; and restrictions on access to such basic necessities as food, clothing and sanitary facilities.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Home isolation, however vital to the fight against the pandemic, is giving still more power to the abuser, Dr. Hester said. “If suddenly people have got to be at home,” she said, “that gives him an opportunity, suddenly, to call the shots around that. To say what she should be doing or shouldn’t.”</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0"> The isolation has also shattered support networks, making it far more difficult for victims to get help or escape.</p><h2 class="css-1aoo5yy eoo0vm40" id="link-41768485">Fragile resources, overwhelmed</h2><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">After her husband attacked her with the high chair, Lele<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>limped to the next room and called the police. When they arrived, however, they only documented the attack, then took no further action.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Next, she hired a lawyer and filed for divorce — only to find that the epidemic had cut off that avenue of escape, too. Her divorce proceeding was postponed until April. She is still waiting for the court’s decision.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">And finding a new home amid the outbreak proved difficult, forcing Lele<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>and her daughter to continue to live with their abuser for weeks.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">It is a pattern playing out around the world.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Institutions that are supposed to protect women from domestic violence, many weak and underfunded to begin with, are now straining to respond to the increased demand.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Feng Yuan, a co-founder of Equality, the Chinese advocacy group, said she had one client who called an emergency line only to be told the police were too overstretched to help her. “We can come to your place after the crisis,” she recounted the operator saying.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">In Europe, one country after another seems to have followed the same grim path: First, governments impose lockdowns without making sufficient provisions for domestic abuse victims. About 10 days later, distress calls spike, setting off a public outcry. Only then do the governments scramble to improvise solutions.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Italy was first.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Its lockdown began in early March. Soon after that, domestic violence reports began to rise, but there was nowhere for newly desperate women to go. Shelters could not take them because the risk of infection was too great.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0"><span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">   </span>So the government said local authorities could requisition hotel rooms to serve as makeshift shelters where victims could quarantine safely.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 ehw59r15"><figure class="css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:258.4222222222222px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-18crmh6 ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Soon after Italy went on lockdown, domestic violence shelters began to fill up.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Spain announced its lockdown on March 14; France’s began three days later. About two weeks later, with abuse reports soaring, officials there announced that they, too, planned to turn vacant hotel rooms into shelters, among other emergency efforts.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">In Britain, the authorities waited longer before imposing a lockdown.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Ten days before it began on March 23,<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>The New York Times contacted the Home Office about what it planned to do about<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>domestic violence. The response:<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>Only “existing sources of advice and support”<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>would be available. The<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>government later published a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-and-domestic-abuse" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">list</a> of hotlines and apps that victims could use to call for help, but only one was specifically tailored for the Covid-19 crisis.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-1fanzo5 StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">By a week into lockdown, Avon and Somerset, in the southwest of the country, said domestic abuse reports were already up by 20 percent, and local forces elsewhere were bracing for the same.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Last week, after dozens of<span class="css-8l6xbc evw5hdy0">  </span>civic groups signed an <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.pilc.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/20200331-Letter-to-MHCLG-DV-and-Covid-19-final-1.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">open letter</a> to the government calling for action, officials pledged to respond, without offering specifics.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">“Supporting victims of domestic abuse is a priority for the home secretary, and she is fully aware of the distress and anxiety this period may cause to those suffering or at risk of domestic abuse,” the Home Office said in a statement. “We are working with the police, domestic abuse charities, help lines and front-line workers to support and protect people,.”</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">It also said victims could “disregard orders to stay at home if they need to seek immediate refuge.”</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">Eventually, the lockdowns will end. But as the confinement drags on, the danger seems likely to intensify. Studies show that abusers are more likely to murder their partners and others in the wake of personal crises, including lost jobs or major financial setbacks.</p><p class="css-axufdj evys1bk0">With Covid-19 ravaging the economy, such crises are set to become much more frequent.</p><p class="css-pncxxs etfikam0">Reporting was contributed by Raphael Minder from Spain, Vivian Wang from Hong Kong, Constant Méheut from France and Elisabetta Povoledo from Italy.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div></section><div></div><div></div><div></div><div></div><div><div id="bottom-wrapper" class="css-1ede5it"><div id="bottom-slug" class="css-l9onyx"><p>Advertisement</p></div><a href="#after-bottom" style="position:absolute;width:1px;height:1px;margin:-1px;padding:0;border:0;clip:rect(0 0 0 0);overflow:hidden">Continue reading the main story</a><div class="ad bottom-wrapper" id="bottom" style="text-align:center;height:100%;display:block;min-height:90px"></div><div id="after-bottom"></div></div></div></article></div></main><nav class="css-kdur8l" id="site-index" aria-labelledby="site-index-label" data-testid="site-index"><h2 class="css-1dv1kvn" Interpreter","collectionType":"COLUMN","uri":"nyt:\u002F\u002Flegacycollection\u002Feb2303ed-3c3e-50f1-a86d-119014fcd6e4","header":"","tagline":"A column and \u003Ca addition to physical violence, which is not present in every abusive relationship, common tools of abuse include isolation from friends, family and employment; constant surveillance; strict, detailed rules for behavior; and restrictions on access to such basic necessities as food, clothing and sanitary facilities.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzExZTE1ZWU5LWJkNDgtNTIwYy05MDUzLTJkNTAwOWQ2ZDIwMw==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.53.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Home isolation, however vital to the fight against the pandemic, is giving still more power to the abuser, Dr. Hester said. “If suddenly people have got to be at home,” she said, “that gives him an opportunity, suddenly, to call the shots around that. To say what she should be doing or shouldn’t.”","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzExZTE1ZWU5LWJkNDgtNTIwYy05MDUzLTJkNTAwOWQ2ZDIwMw==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.55.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" The isolation has also shattered support networks, making it far more difficult for victims to get help or escape.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzExZTE1ZWU5LWJkNDgtNTIwYy05MDUzLTJkNTAwOWQ2ZDIwMw==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.57.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Fragile resources, overwhelmed","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzExZTE1ZWU5LWJkNDgtNTIwYy05MDUzLTJkNTAwOWQ2ZDIwMw==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.58.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"After her husband attacked her with the high chair, Lele  limped to the next room and called the police.
